title: Links for February 2014
summary:
Key ideas:
- A writer takes pharmacological opposites of common drugs of abuse to test sobriety
- Impaired chewing ability can cause cognitive dysfunction
- A school in New Zealand gets rid of restrictive rules and bullying decreases
- The pathogen causing Justinian’s Plague and possibly Periclean Plague is yersinia pestis
- Labeling obesity as a disease may not encourage people to lose weight
- A patient is charged $89,000 for antivenom available online for $750
- Psychoanalytic psychotherapy is not significantly better than other therapies
- Charter schools increase students' future income and likelihood of college enrollment
- The collapse of the "Great Gatsby Curve" shows rising income inequality does not decrease social mobility
- A Malaysian newspaper finds Civilization V offensive
- Scott discusses the importance of having a structure to be productive and achieve goals.
- He encourages breaking down goals into smaller tasks and following a routine.
- He emphasizes the importance of sticking to the structure, even when it feels difficult.

Key learnings:
- Weird ways the face interacts with the brain can impact cognitive function
- Relaxing restrictive rules can decrease bullying
- Implications of labeling certain conditions/diseases may require more consideration
- Regulations may negatively affect effective education
- Psychoanalytic psychotherapy may not be significantly more effective than other therapies
- Charter schools may be a viable alternative to public schools
- Rising income inequality does not necessarily decrease social mobility
- Having a structure and routine can help with productivity and achieving goals.
- Breaking down goals into smaller tasks can make them feel more manageable.
- It can be difficult to stick to the structure, but it is important to do so.

Key questions:
- Can pharmacological opposites of drugs of abuse be used to promote sobriety in rehab programs?
- Can chewing gum be used to stimulate the brain and prevent cognitive dysfunction in elderly people?
- Could the removal of restrictive rules in schools worldwide be a solution for bullying?
- Will the concept of a dormant pathogen that goes viral every 800 years have any implications in disease prevention?
- How can we combat the negative effects of labeling certain conditions/diseases?
- Should regulators shut down effective education programs?
- How can we improve accessibility and affordability of effective therapies?
- Will alternative forms of education like charter schools become more widespread?
- How can we address rising income inequality and lack of social mobility?
- How can one establish a structure that works best for them?
- How can one motivate themselves to stick to the structure?
- How can one adjust the structure if it is not working effectively?
